image.altText: A sketch of Malka Leifer wearing a hair wrap.

items.synopsis: Former school principal Malka Leifer is being sentenced in a Melbourne court for 18 sexual offences, including rape and indecent assault. Follow live.

title.children: Sentencing underway for former school principal Malka Leifer

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ABC reporter Kristian Silva is covering the sentencing of Malka Leifer. He provided us with this description of the scene inside the court room. Ted Baillieu, the former Victorian premier and long-time supporter of sisters Nicole, Elly and Dassi is here, as is Liberal MP David Southwick. The three sisters are in the front row of the gallery, behind the prosecution legal team that was spearheaded by Justin Lewis. Of course, plenty of reporters are here too. Malka Leifer is being beamed into the courtroom via videolink on a large screen on the left side of the room. Leifer is in a small room of the Dame Phyllis Frost Centre, and is wearing a bright blue jumper and navy headscarf. The disgraced principal is rocking lightly back and forth, her left hand covering her mouth.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Supporters gather inside court room

children.content: ABC reporter Kristian Silva is covering the sentencing of Malka Leifer.
He provided us with this description of the scene inside the court room.
Ted Baillieu, the former Victorian premier and long-time supporter of sisters Nicole, Elly and Dassi is here, as is Liberal MP David Southwick.
The three sisters are in the front row of the gallery, behind the prosecution legal team that was spearheaded by Justin Lewis. Of course, plenty of reporters are here too.
Malka Leifer is being beamed into the courtroom via videolink on a large screen on the left side of the room.
Leifer is in a small room of the Dame Phyllis Frost Centre, and is wearing a bright blue jumper and navy headscarf.
The disgraced principal is rocking lightly back and forth, her left hand covering her mouth.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Judge Gamble outlines how at home, the sisters had "no access to TV, the internet or newspapers". "And the only books or magazines they had access to at home were those approved by their parents and written by Jewish authors," he says. "Similarly at school, books were sometimes altered in various ways to ensure the text and illustrations accorded with ultra-orthodox teachings and values, including modesty." He says Leifer's victims were "ignorant" in sexual matters, having received no form of sexual education either at home or at school. "In effect, each of them had no understanding of the sexual nature of the acts Mrs Leifer was engaging in," Judge Gamble says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sisters had 'very little understanding' of world outside ultra-Orthodox community

children.content: Judge Gamble outlines how at home, the sisters had "no access to TV, the internet or newspapers".
"And the only books or magazines they had access to at home were those approved by their parents and written by Jewish authors," he says.
"Similarly at school, books were sometimes altered in various ways to ensure the text and illustrations accorded with ultra-orthodox teachings and values, including modesty."
He says Leifer's victims were "ignorant" in sexual matters, having received no form of sexual education either at home or at school.
"In effect, each of them had no understanding of the sexual nature of the acts Mrs Leifer was engaging in," Judge Gamble says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The three sisters at the centre of this case say they're expecting to be speaking for the next 24 hours about the sentencing but are hoping they can then move on with their lives. "This for us is one of the final steps of the journey," Dassi Erlich said outside court. "We're all incredibly nervous. We're going in with low expectations, hoping that we don't see a predator back on the streets too soon. "We all know that nothing is really going to reflect what she did to us." Nicole Meyer said the sisters want to focus their energy in other areas. "We are looking to really put this behind us and start new chapters of healing whether it's helping the community, studying law, social work, all different areas of life
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sentencing 'the final step of the journey'

children.content: The three sisters at the centre of this case say they're expecting to be speaking for the next 24 hours about the sentencing but are hoping they can then move on with their lives.
"This for us is one of the final steps of the journey," Dassi Erlich said outside court.
Dassi Erlich spoke outside court.
(ABC News: Danielle Bonica)
"We're all incredibly nervous. We're going in with low expectations, hoping that we don't see a predator back on the streets too soon.
"We all know that nothing is really going to reflect what she did to us."
Elly Sapper paused briefly to speak to the media this morning.
(ABC News: Danielle Bonica)
Nicole Meyer said the sisters want to focus their energy in other areas.
"We are looking to really put this behind us and start new chapters of healing whether it's helping the community, studying law, social work, all different areas of life

image.altText: Founder of Wagner private mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin in military gear.

items.synopsis: Ten people died after a private jet crashed in Russia's Tver region north of Moscow, Russia's TASS news agency reports.

title.children: Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin killed in plane crash two months after mutiny, Russia's civil aviation authority says

image.altText: Smoke arises from the site of a jet crash near Moscow.

items.synopsis: Warlord Yevgeny Prigozhin was on the passenger list for a private jet that crashed between Moscow and St Petersburg, Russian state media is reporting.

title.children: Prigozhin 'died as a result of the actions of traitors to Russia' says Wagner group, confirming plane crash

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What we have so far is a Wagner-linked plane that went down, and a passenger list with Yevgeny Prigozhin's name on it. Russian authorities are still identifying the remains of those on board, however they have not yet confirmed Prigozhin is among the bodies. We've seen Wagner-linked Telegram channels posting tributes to Prigozhin. As we just saw, there are makeshift memorials popping up at Wagner HQ in St Petersburg. However, in Russia, everything is not always as it seems. There have been reports of a second jet owned by Prigozhin that landed safely in Moscow. Some security analysts have speculated that the crash could be a ploy to allow the Wagner chief to disappear quietly into a life of obscurity. Keir Giles, a Russia expert with international affairs think tank Chatham House, was among those urging caution about reports of Prigozhin's death earlier today. He pointed out that "multiple individuals have changed their name to Yevgeny Prigozhin", as part of his efforts to make it harder for his enemies to track his movements. So it may be some time before we can confirm Prigozhin's status.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why can't we be sure Prigozhin is dead?

children.content: What we have so far is a Wagner-linked plane that went down, and a passenger list with Yevgeny Prigozhin's name on it. Russian authorities are still identifying the remains of those on board,
however they have not yet confirmed Prigozhin is among the bodies.
We've seen Wagner-linked Telegram channels posting tributes to Prigozhin. As we just saw, there are makeshift memorials popping up at Wagner HQ in St Petersburg.

However, in Russia, everything is not always as it seems. There have been reports of a second jet owned by Prigozhin that landed safely in Moscow. Some security analysts have speculated that the crash could be a ploy to allow the Wagner chief to disappear quietly into a life of obscurity.

Keir Giles, a Russia expert with international affairs think tank Chatham House, was among those urging caution about reports of Prigozhin's death earlier today. He pointed out that "multiple individuals have changed their name to Yevgeny Prigozhin", as part of his efforts to make it harder for his enemies to track his movements.
So it may be some time before we can confirm Prigozhin's status.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reuters is reporting that the jet model that crashed, with Prigozhin believed to be on board, had a solid safety record, with only one accident recorded in its 20 years of service. Russia's TASS news agency has identified the plane that crashed as a Brazilian Embraer jet known as the Legacy 600, one of the best private jets on the market. The following Embraer jet, registration number RA-02795, is identified by Flightradar24 as belonging to the Wagner group: The flight tracking website showed it dropped off the radar at 6:11pm local time (1:11am AEST). The Legacy 600 first entered service in 2002, according to International Aviation HQ, with almost 300 produced until production ceased in 2020. There is only one recorded accident involving a Legacy 600. In 2006, an Embraer Legacy 600 crashed midair into a Gol 737-800 on its way from the factory in Brazil to the United States. Despite damages to the aircraft, the pilot landed the plane and there were no deaths or injuries. A subsequent inquiry attributed blame to the crew rather than any mechanical failure.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Embraer jet that crashed had a solid safety record

children.content: Reuters is reporting that the jet model that crashed, with Prigozhin believed to be on board, had a solid safety record, with only one accident recorded in its 20 years of service.
Russia's TASS news agency has identified the plane that crashed as a Brazilian Embraer jet known as the Legacy 600, one of the best private jets on the market.
The following Embraer jet, registration number RA-02795, is identified by Flightradar24 as belonging to the Wagner group:

The Legacy 600 first entered service in 2002, according to International Aviation HQ, with almost 300 produced until production ceased in 2020.
There is only one recorded accident involving a Legacy 600. In 2006,
an Embraer Legacy 600 crashed midair into a Gol 737-800 on its way from the factory in Brazil to the United States
. Despite damages to the aircraft, the pilot landed the plane and there were no deaths or injuries. A subsequent inquiry attributed blame to the crew rather than any mechanical failure.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Big-serving American John Isner will call time on his career after the upcoming US Open. Isner, 38, turned pro in 2007 and reached a career high of world number eight. He won 16 singles titles, the biggest being the Miami Open crown in 2018, his most successful season. "After 17+ years on the @atptour, it's time to say goodbye to professional tennis," Isner said on social media site X, formerly known as Twitter. "This transition won't be easy but I'm looking forward to every second of it with my amazing family. The @usopen will be my final event. Time to lace 'em up one last time." The towering North Carolina native crushed an ATP-record 14,411 aces in his career and has the fastest serve ever officially recorded, a 253 kph bomb he unleashed in the first round of the 2016 Davis Cup. He came out on the winning side of the longest pro tennis match in history, which lasted 11 hours and 5 minutes and took place over three days at Wimbledon in 2010. After 183 games in that match, Isner defeated qualifier Nicolas Mahut in the first round. Wimbledon would later institute a rule change to ensure a similarly long match would not take place again. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: John Isner, winner of the longest pro tennis match in history,  to retire after US open

props.alt: John Isner in a white shirt holding a tennis racket

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Researchers may have solved the mystery of why pearl octopi have been huddling together to protect their eggs at the bottom of the ocean off the California coast. They believe heat seeping up from the base of an extinct underwater volcano helps their eggs hatch faster. "There are clear advantages of basically sitting in this natural hot tub," says Janet Voight, an octopus biologist at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago. The researchers calculated that the heated nest location more than halves the time it takes for eggs laid there to hatch — reducing the risk of them being munched by snails, shrimp and other predators. The nesting site, which the scientists dubbed an "octopus garden", was first discovered in 2018 by researchers from the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and other institutions. The team used an underwater remote vehicle to film the throng of nearly 6,000 octopus nesting 2 miles deep. "It was completely incredible — we suddenly saw thousands of pearly-coloured octopus, all upside down, with their legs up in the air and moving around. They were pushing away potential predators and turning over their eggs," marine biologist Andrew DeVogelaere says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Deep-sea 'hot tubs' help octopus eggs hatch faster

props.alt: octupus in the cracks of a ocean floor

children.content: Muusoctopus robustus females nesting in cracks influenced by hydrothermal springs
(Science Advances)
Researchers may have solved the mystery of why pearl octopi have been huddling together to protect their eggs at the bottom of the ocean off the California coast.
They believe heat seeping up from the base of an extinct underwater volcano helps their eggs hatch faster.
"There are clear advantages of basically sitting in this natural hot tub," says Janet Voight, an octopus biologist at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago.

The researchers calculated that the heated nest location more than halves the time it takes for eggs laid there to hatch — reducing the risk of them being munched by snails, shrimp and other predators.

nesting 2 miles deep.

"It was completely incredible — we suddenly saw thousands of pearly-coloured octopus, all upside down, with their legs up in the air and moving around. They were pushing away potential predators and turning over their eggs," marine biologist Andrew DeVogelaere says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has recorded an annual profit of $1.7 billion in the last financial year, a dramatic turnaround from a loss of $860 million a year earlier. Its preferred underlying pre-tax profit measure figure is $2.5 billion, and comes after Qantas posted a $1.4 billion profit in its half-yearly results in February. It's the first time since 2019 that Qantas has reported an annual profit, after three years of sustained losses during the COVID-19 pandemic, which grounded the aviation industry. Today’s annual results for the airline are the last from Alan Joyce as CEO before he hands the reins to chief financial officer Vanessa Hudson in November.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas records annual profit of $1.7 billion

featuredLink.title: Qantas records $1.7 billion profit after years of COVID-induced turbulence

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Daniel Ziffer from the ABC's business team with you. The financial results of our national carrier Qantas will be revealed today. There's a lot of criticism of the airline, which in recent years has sacked thousands of workers, lost bags and been accused of running down the brand, to the extent that outgoing CEO Alan Joyce last year said it was "routinely letting customers down". How will shareholders feel later today? And central bankers will meet in the US resort of Jackson Hole. In winter it gets incredible snow and I'd really like to visit, so you're going to be subjected to GIFs like this until I can arrange a "study tour" to preview future meetings. US indicies closed up overnight, the Dow was +0.5% to 34,472.98 points, the broader S & P 500 +1.1% to 4,436.01 points and the tech-laden Nasdaq +1.59% to 13,721.03 points. More to come! (By which I mean skiing GIFs and information).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will Qantas fly or falter?

image.altText: A woman in a tuckshop kitchen puts a meal into a brown bag

items.synopsis: For just $5, students and staff can get a decent lunch at Raelene Akers' school, and it sees hundreds of tuckshop orders roll in some days despite cost-of-living-pressures.

title.children: Why school canteens are thriving despite the cost-of-living crunch for parents

image.altText: A pen of lambs in a saleyard in Bairnsdale.

items.synopsis: Consumers continue to pay high prices for meat while farmers say the prices they are getting are not worth sending their livestock to market.

title.children: 'Someone is making a dollar': Farmers shoot sheep rather than take them to market at a loss

image.altText: Don and Gail, dressed in warm jackets, smile as they stand in front of the sea on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: A memorial service will be held in Korumburra next week for Don and Gail Patterson, who died last month from suspected mushroom poisoning in Victoria's east.

title.children: Public memorial to be held for suspected mushroom-poisoning victims Don and Gail Patterson

image.altText: Frank Dimasi, wearing a checkered shirt, standing in front of grape vines with no grapes.

items.synopsis: Victorian irrigators are happy the state has opted out of the federal government's new basin plan, but are worried about what water buybacks in other states will do to farming in Australia.

title.children: Victoria has gone rogue on the new Murray-Darling Basin Plan and farmers are overjoyed. Here's why

image.altText: India moon lander's view of the moon from space.

items.synopsis: India becomes the first country to land near the Moon's south pole, just days after a Russian spacecraft crashed trying to reach the area.

title.children: 'Witnessing history': India celebrates being first to ever land on south pole of the Moon

image.altText: Before and after slider

items.synopsis: California's Death Valley National Park has had a year's worth of rain in a day due to Tropical Storm Hilary. This is what it looks like on the ground.

title.children: 'Who has flood insurance in a desert?': Before and after images show destruction caused by record rain in California
